propose.translation[0].definitions[0].de: to suggest something as a plan or course of action
propose.translation[0].definitions[0].ex: The changes were first proposed last year.
In his speech he proposed that the UN should set up an emergency centre for the environment.
The report also proposes expanding the airport.
He proposed a compromise to me.
propose.translation[0].definitions[0].no: In everyday English, people usually say that someone puts forward plans, ideas etc, rather than proposes them:
The idea was first put forward by a German scientist.
propose.translation[0].definitions[1].de: to formally suggest a course of action at a meeting and ask people to vote on it
propose.translation[0].definitions[1].ex: The resolution was proposed by the chairman of the International Committee.
Mr Leesom proposed Mrs Banks for the position of Treasurer  (=he suggested formally that she should be the treasurer).
propose.translation[0].definitions[2].de: to suggest an idea, method etc as an answer to a scientific question or as a better way of doing something
propose.translation[0].definitions[2].ex: A number of theories have been proposed to explain the phenomenon.
propose.translation[0].definitions[3].ex: How does he propose to deal with the situation?
We still don’t know how the company proposes raising the money.
propose.translation[0].definitions[4].de: to ask someone to marry you, especially in a formal way
propose.translation[0].definitions[4].ex: Shaun proposed to me only six months after we met.
propose.translation[0].definitions[5].de: to ask someone to marry you
propose.translation[0].note_box[0].items: In everyday English, you propose that someone does something
I propose that Ms Hallam is appointed
In more formal English, you propose that someone do something, using the base form of the verb  (=infinitive without ‘to’)
I propose that Ms Hallam be appointed
I propose Ms Hallam to be appointed
You can also use the base form when talking about the past
I proposed that Ms Hallam be appointed
You propose that someone should do something  This pattern is used especially in British English
He proposed that we should have another meeting
You say it was proposed that someone  (should) do something
It was proposed that we (should) have another meeting
propose.translation[1].definitions[0].de: to suggest something such as a plan or course of action
propose.translation[1].definitions[0].ex: Lyle proposed large cuts in the training budget.
Hansen has proposed that I become his business partner.
propose.translation[1].definitions[1].de: to formally suggest a course of action at a meeting and ask people to vote on it
propose.translation[1].definitions[1].ex: The chairman proposed a scheme to save both the company and investors’ funds.
He will propose a motion at Monday’s special meeting, calling on the committee to reverse its decision.
propose.translation[1].definitions[2].ex: Which of his assets is he proposing to sell?
The Sales Director is proposing to boost sales by spending an additional £3,000 per month on advertising.
